description:
This place knows how to make some great Chinese food! Support your local, family-owned business for some easy, casual Chinese food. They have have some nice big tables for big families and some for small parties as well.

Great service, just remember to be patient, as food should never be rushed and everyone is human and makes mistakes!
author: Mia C.

description:
Inexpensive but the food was pretty standard so it doesn't really stand-out from any other Chinese restaurant.

Owner was pretty friendly.
author: Steve A.

description:
Pretty good delivery chinese restaurant. I'm a huge fan of that "American-Chinese" delivery food aka General Tso's, beef with brocoli, etc. So this review is based on that food.

Delivery was quick, the g tso's was tasty. Will definitely order (and have already ordered multiple times) again!
author: Don H.

description: I have to say my son ordered some food from here one night and ever since then we always order from them!I even like going to the Restruant there.Everyone is very welcoming and nice there,I would definitely recommend this Restruant to everyone
author: ANNA N.

description: We just order delivery and the food was very bad. We ordered $80 dollars worth. The wonton was burnt! The the lemon chicken, I think they forgot to put the lemon on lemon chicken. Whoever was the cook on this night forgot that you are suppose to season the food. The chow mien had no flavor. Do not order to take out because the food is way better eating in!!! Way disappointed.
author: Annie P.

description:
Went here for Father's Day lunch. I was surprised how not busy it was. The food took a long time to come out, but it seems like they cook the dishes fresh (I kind of peaked into the kitchen on the way to the bathroom hehe). The service was pretty good. For a party of 4 (3 guys) with no left overs, it was about $100 for 6 dishes:

1. Twice Cooked Pork - my fav dish out of the 6
2. Szechuan Spices Spare Ribs - second fav dish
3. Sauteed Eel strips - least favorite, no flavor, not to crazy about the slimey texture either 
4. Shanghai Style Shrimp - ehh.. not much flavor 
5. Shredded Tofu dish - pretty good
6. Fish and mushroom dish - just alright.. kind of bland. 

 It's an average food place, and the serving sizes are pretty small. I probably would not come back here again or ever crave their food.
author: Leah A.

description: We enjoy the fresh vegetables and vegetarian dishes. Its one of our favs for takeout in the sunset. When we ordered online & then we received a friendly call to confirm we wanted our "Free" dish also vegetarian. That's great service!  ;-)
author: Jennifer C.

description: Ordered their salt pepper pork chop and it was too salty. Asked them nicely to replace it and still came out too salty. It also tasted like they just rinse the pork and refried it, very bland and extra extra crispy. Their Shanghai noodle was too oily too. Waste of calories. Never going there back again. No thanks!
author: Lyn B.

description:
Peking is a good Chinese restaurant near 19th Ave. on Noriega. I found this place on accident, once the Korean place I like across the street seems to be closed down. The hot and sour soup is awesome, not too hot or too sour with a very deep rich broth that makes it one of the best hot and sour soup I've ever tasted! 

Both times I've been here I ordered the spicy house chicken, and it is very good with black mushrooms.  The lunch specials cost about six dollars and range up to nine dollars at most. The service is typical to Chinese restaurants, spotty at times, but that's OK. Come here for the hot and sour soup alone, and you end up ordering several things off the menu. Will be back soon to explore the menu, and provide an update.
author: Marlon T.

description: Came to this restaurant by chance and have since become a regular. Great food, great service, and reasonable prices. Love this place!
author: Samantha L.

description: Ordered delivery from this restaurant and it arrived quickly, still hot and DELICIOUS! One of my new favs...!
author: Bert R.

description: We've been coming to this place for a long time but usually order delivery food to our house for a small friend's parties.  The best Chinese food in town, very good portions, and not expensive.  We got addicted to the food from this place every time we are up for Chinese!
author: Alex T.

description:
I typically only have Chinese food (other than dim sum) when I have dinner with the family or when I order delivery. Wanting to try a new place, the roommate and I ordered delivery through delivery dot com.

December 2013
*Hot spiced house chicken ($7.95) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/peking-restaurant-san-francisco#ZhRKalCL3RqP_bXKq-s-nA
*Mixed fried rice ($6.95) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/peking-restaurant-san-francisco#8KNqiZGs51QRZbUGzvn-Cg
*Sauteed dry string beans with pork ($7.95) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/peking-restaurant-san-francisco#E4h6JAsQwoLOGs0T9ybILA
*Marinated jelly fish ($8.95) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/peking-restaurant-san-francisco#EjqO_tbEH7rk2XJkRl1kTQ
*Beef chow fun ($6.95) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/peking-restaurant-san-francisco#7vHJ8TVPidrRv2t75a2tGg
*Wonton soup (small $4.95) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/peking-restaurant-san-francisco#28fPG-1fJxagRRejOJs0HA

I'd been through a string of getting tasteless beef chow fun so I was pleasantly surprised when Peking restaurant's version was full of flavor. I didn't have to add anything to give it taste! The green beans were good too. Still retained a nice crunch. The roommate ordered the chicken since he wanted to try something new. It wasn't very good and not really that spicy. It did have black mushrooms which I love eating. The rest of the dishes were pretty average.

Decent chinese food and pretty good prices for delivery.
author: Elena N.

description:
Our family has been coming to Peking for decades. Though the neighborhood has changed quite a bit over the years Peking has stayed the same.  This fact is a testament to the delicious food, kind staff, and comfortable environment. No corking fee, no cake slicing fee, can support large parties, delicious, inexpensive, quite. I will keep coming back for more, thanks Peking :)

My Favorite dishes:

Egg roll
Sweet/sour soup
Sizzling rice soup
Crispy duck
Szechuan Egg Plant
Mongolian Beef
Chow fun
Chow mien
Fried rice
author: Sergey D.

description: About 2 hours for dinner for a party of 6 people on a weekend bc they are really low on staff. I had to stand up multiples times myself to get my own water, to get my to go boxes and the check bc the waiters were so spread out thin. They need to hire more waiters for weekend nights! I asked the manager to hire more staff. Don't go if you are going for a business dinner or have less than 2 hours to eat.
author: Sofia J.

description: Really great family owned restaurant that has been around for over 20 years.  The prices are decent, and there are so many yummy dishes to choose from. Some of my favorites are the eggplant in hot garlic sauce, sweet and sour fish filet, Mongolian lamb or beef, and fish filet in black bean sauce. The service is also very good.
author: Emily G.

description:
Nancy is the best! My favorite Chinese food in the sunset.

The Kung-Pao chicken is soooo good over steamed white rice. 

I also always get the broccoli shrimp with Jalepenos and the sweet and sour chicken chicken with pineapple!
author: Chung L.

description: Love love love, this place. Best traditional tasty Chinese. Been eating here for 15+ years. Thank you.
author: Eva R.

description: Good food, however, needs more consistency in quality. Ordered seafood soup and got one shrimp in the whole thing. It also had a poor taste. The Mongolian beef is great, highly recommended.
author: Fernando G.

description: Great family restaurant with friendly setvice and tasty food! Their Seafood Party was delicious and their sizzling rice soup is perfect to get over a cold.
author: Cecilia R.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurant in San Francisco. Staff are friendly, the food is delicious, too.
author: Joan W.

description:
Ordered Generals Chicken, Cashew Chicken, and steamed rice.  I don't know if it's an off day or what, but the food was terrible and very disappointing.  

Generals Chicken:  It's supposed to be spicy, but the sauce had a mild orange taste and was somewhat sweet.  Too much breading, not enough chicken.  Definitely does not taste fresh, tastes like leftovers.  Gross.

Cashew Chicken:  Bland, bland, bland.

The only thing that was right was the sticky rice.  What a waste of $20!
author: J C.

description: I've been coming here since I was a boy. Great Chinese food!
author: Julio B.

description: Very low stuff and long waiting time. Big plates but small amount of food. Ordered some beef then figured out only ur top layer was beef, the bottom layer was made of rice noodles and vegetables. I don't like business which plays smart on its customers. The waitress was polite and nice, but she doesn't make up all the negative aspects I mentioned above.
author: Bo L.

description:
I use to love this place.  food was really good and I always stopped by when I could but after my last experience there won't be a next time

we ordered hot and sour soup, chicken chow mein and the orange chicken.  the soup was awesome, the chow mein was below average and the orange chicken didn't even taste like chicken.  it was soggy and bland.  as I was leaving I told our waiter (who never stopped by to ask us about our meal, even though we were the only people in the place) how bad the food was, he apologized but so what.
author: Robert S.

description:
I have been coming here since I was in high school and I must say that it hits the spot quite well.

It's in a more quieter part of the city and there is more parking available at certain times of the day.

The menu is pretty set with simple and traditional Chinese food. The atmosphere is very quiet and the service is always good.
author: Elisabeth R.

description: Our favorite Chinese! I have to say parking sucks! It's a bit dingy inside but the food is SO GOOD! By far the best won ton soup around! Hits the spot every time we're craving it on a cold rainy day. We have yet to try a dish we didn't like. Service is always good. It's a bit pricy but definitely worth it.
author: Carina P.

description: We have lived in the Sunset for 15 years, and either eat here, or have delivery at least once a month (more than any other restaurant).  The food is always good, and we still try new things and are happily surprised.  Our favorites are the baked prawns, mongolian beef, and pot stickers.   We have relatives from L.A. who insist on coming here every time they visit, instead of Chinatown.  If you are a regular, you can ask them to stock your favorite wine (KJ Chardonnay for us). They are the best on Noriega.
author: Brayton F.

description: Family has been coming here since 1984. Hasn't changed much, and that's what keeps us coming back. Their Peking beef, chow mein, and garlic chicken are delicious, but so are the other dishes on their fairly long menu. Service is great and friendly- they treat us like family here. Highly recommend. They can accommodate large family dinners pretty easily, too.
author: Ed S.

description: I love coming here because the waitstaff is always pleasant & curtious. They even remember my mom even though she hasn't been here in 2 1/2 yrs. I highly recommend.
author: Monica D.

description:
Got delivery.  The fried rice tasted like ketchup =(  The rest of the food was missing something...but I couldn't put my finger on what.

Definitely did not love the food. Going to continue somewhere else
author: H B.

description: Our go to Chinese restaurant for delivery in the Sunset District. Been ordering from here for many years. Won ton soup is especially good for those cold, foggy, drizzly nights on the west side of SF. Never been disappointed with the food here. All the mainstay dishes are always on point. They even give you a free chow mein or fried rice order if you order what amounts to 2-3 dishes. Very good and fast delivery. If they are busy, they will be sure to let you know so you are not wondering where your food is. Give them a try.
author: Val T.

description: I have been coming here for years. They have the best garlic chicken in town! Their hot and sour soup is pretty tasty also.
author: Karen L.

description: Update: had diarrhea few hours after I ate their food...never happened before but it was pretty bad this time..
author: Chi Yi L.

description: It was a Saturday night. Maybe half the restaurant was packed. Took awhile to have our order taken. Took even longer for the food to get here. About 35-45 minutes wait on food. The food was not too bad. I think it depends on what you order. Busy night, they should have more than just one lady working the tables.
author: Tee T.

description: Placed an order. Got a call from grubhub 45 mins later that the restaurant is closed. It was open when I placed the order. Never again.
author: Katya P.

description:
Peking is one of the best Chinese Restaurants not only for their great service but the food is yummie. We are a Vegetarian  family and enjoy that they have some great selections. 
We placed an order online on their website which is pretty user friendly I must say. Then we received a call because she noticed we ordered a soup that wasn't vegetarian and wanted to make sure we meant to do that. Then she offered to make it without the meat. 
What amazing service! Plus when you order online they offer some great deals!
I would definitely recommend.
author: Derek G.

description: I thought the food could have been better. The dumpling skins were too thick and lacked soup. The Shanghai panfried noodles were my favorite, but they did lack some flavor. I was not a fan of the soup they offered and their dessert at the end had little bits of flowers which was interesting, but it was good. The shrimp was bland as well. Not sure if I want to be back since I wasn't impressed with anything they served.
author: Amanda C.

description: Tried a new place after the old standby disappointed one too many times.  All dishes were fresh & delicious.  Delivery was timed as promised and their employee was friendly & pleasant.  Be sure to stir any entrees with sauce before plating.
author: Deb S.

description: I have been going to Peking Restaurant for years.  It is great food, friendly staff.  The at-home delivery is always prompt.  The food is always hot.  I definitely recommend Peking on Noriega Street.
author: Diana S.

description: Hot and sour soup is the best in town! And I've tried a lot of places in SF! Their walnut prawns are also amazing!
author: Lauren C.

description:
This place is a Chinese food staple in the city of San Francisco.  The Szechuan prawns are done to utter perfection.  As a native this is the go to restaurant for our entire family.  

Anything and everything you order from here is top notch.  This place never disappoints.
author: Dan C.

description: First time here not too many people but don't be deceived there food is great. I LOVE their hot and sour soup!!!!! There service was amazing, they really do care about giving great customer service.
author: Orange G.

description:
would not order again

fried rice with pork = greasy white rice with fatty pork
fried wontons = fried wontons with one piece of pork folded in the corner
onion pancakes were ok.
author: Emma M.

description: I've honestly never returned delivery food before, and almost never send food back in restaurants, but this food was exceptionally terrible.  My boyfriend and I could not even eat it because parts of it tasted rotten... nevermind the soggy, bland noodles and tofu.  Very disappointed.  2 stars because they politely handled the ordeal and gave our money back.  Still would never eat here again though.
author: Justine K.

description: Great food! I had the Orange Beef as takeout. I asked for it to be extremely spicy, and they delivered. :) One of the best tasting Chinese dishes I've had in years!
author: John A.

description: It's average. The chicken wings and noodles were okay, the shrimp dumplings were average as well. There's plenty of room though parking can be a major pain in the area.
author: Tiff W.

description:
I've only been here a few times but it's pricy. The place is really good though but make sure to order your plate over rice if that's what you want. The place is very authentic and friendly people. My roommate likes going their more than me, I like little 
Across the steet. I live 4 houses down from Noriega
author: Rob T.

description:
I have to completely disagree with all the negative reviews about this place. Of course we've only been in a couple of times generally we have delivery. 

All the steamed dishes are prepared perfectly; very clean and not greasy. The sweet stuff is sweet; the savory stuff is savory. 

And they're only three blocks from the house so delivery is always fast. 

Highly recommended!
author: Bill M.

description:
I've never had a bad experience here. There might be some dishes I wouldn't order again since I was just curious to try, but majority of the time I've been greatly satisfied. I haven't heard a complaint from any friends or family I've brought here.

 I've been eating here for a few years and I'm curious if people know that they have 2 menus? A americanized menu and a chinese menu which has english for the most part. This isn't just like most chinese restaurants out there. It specializes more in Szechuan style cuisine if I'm not wrong. its not the usual hongkong style cuisine you're probably looking for.  

just gonna list some dishes I've had recently.

 - jellyfish (one of the best I've had and has a good bite to it).
  - szechuan spicy peanuts and beancurd. good for beer and rice
- beer hotpot with intestines. ok not everyone will go for this but this is a great dish especially with rice of course
- lemon chicken- ok i don't normally order this but had it once. I was mostly impressed they used a glass glaze instead of the yellow food coloring garbage like most restaurants do. 
-hong kong style shrimp - fried shrimp with fried minced garlic and sesame.
-cumin lamb - good flavors
- fried rice - this place actually makes some really good fried rice. got it free too from grabbing take out. 
- I don't know the english name, but its like a dumpling wine dessert. I mainly like the fragrance and the little sesame dumplings that come with it.
author: Myron L.

description: I have been going to Peking for years but the quality has changed.  There pick up orders are a disappointment. Today when I got the hot and sour soup, the soup had no shrimp and little other meat and the chow mein was the same.   This is the second time my order had missing ingredients that I didn't discover until I got home. A neighborhood place that no longer a good place to pick up food. Mary
author: Mary H.

description:
My friend had her wedding rehearsal dinner here so we pretty much took over the whole restaurant.  I don't remember how many courses we had but the food just kept on coming.  The interior is kind of small and dingy, and it took awhile for some of the food to come out, but maybe its because we bombarded the restaurant all at once and they didn't know how to handle the crowd.

Everything tastes authentic, but nothing was memorable.  I do remember thinking the xiao long baos were just okay - the soup inside wasn't that flavorful and the skin could've been thinner.
author: Angela C.

description:
Outstanding soup noodles

Came back for a quiet lunch on Saturday and tried the soup noodles.  The spicy beef noodles were extremely well prepared in tasty noodles with tender beef and tendons cooked to soft chewy consistency.  Their Peking noodles were really packed with delicious ingredients like napa, fungus, shrimp, beef and pork.  These were both very good, Hugh portioned dishes.  Perfect for a cold day!   For 8 bucks this is a bargain.
author: Bad News S.

description: Honestly one of my favorite Chinese restaurants in the city!!! This place is absolutely not fancy at all, but the food here is delicious!!! I usually order from her to go orders and they are always super fast and they get my orders correct every time. My bf and I actually took grandparents and parents here on Father's Day this past week because its a couple blocks away for grandparents and the serves and food was as always amazing!!!!
author: G O.

description:
My family has been coming to this restaurant since the early 90's. We've moved further and further away from the place over the years, but we travel just to enjoy our all-time favorites - the best ever szechuan prawns, super tasty wonton soup and the to-die-for combo fried rice.  
John the owner and chef is amazing.  I hope when he retires, he'll pass on the superb recipes to the new owners.  Until then, we'll keep on coming back - a 1.5 hour trip well-worth it.
author: Malou A.

description: General's chicken and BBQ pork chow mein were hot and delivered promptly. Tasted amazing.
author: Fhinz B.

description: I have to say, I am slightly biased in writing my review. My father's friend is the owner of this restaurant and we had always gone there when we lived in SF. It had such a friendly staff and they were always willing to cook vegetarian dishes for my family. The food is authentically made.
author: Laurie H.

description: The best Chinese restaurant serving authentic southwest spicy food! Every dish just blow my mind, even the complimentary dessert is so good. Service is fantastic and feel like home. Definitely going to visit again if I go to SF area!
author: Sophia H.

description: Walked by decided to try lunch special got Cashew chicken was super bland didn't have brown rice either.  I would suggest try one of the others around here I kinda wished I had some MSG was not very well flavored.  They were nice pace was a little dingy carpet needs replaced.
author: Nirea S.

description: I like that place.. Very good hot and sour soup and Mongolian beef just perfect!!! I give them five stars. I know that place for 22 years, I think it's the best Chinese restaurant  in sunset area.
author: Mikhail M.

description:
Back in its heyday, This place was the bomb. Now, just an old, greasy place with lousy food. 

How can you mess up Vegetarian Chow Mien? How about douse it with MSG.

Waitresses were friendly and great to look at but if I wanted to look at cougars, Id go to the Zoo.
author: Mario A.

description: I came here last night after an appointment at UCSF as I love trying a new place each time I am up hyere.  Nancy is very nice & ames to please.  I love the traditional dacor including the chairs with the backsw having a traditional Chinese design.  The boiled meat dumplings are very fragrent with a perfectly thin wrapper & ground pork & spice filling; perfect with soy sauce.  The green onion pancakes are thin, crispy, & greasless; the right amount of onions & wonde34rful with the smooth peanut sauce.  The basil chicken, a Taiwanese dish, is wonderful with tender chicken, leeks, & fresh basil in a wonderful sauce.  The bean sauce noodles are wonderful with aldente noodles, ground beef, pickled vegetables, soy beans, & a very flavorful bean sauce; I have plenty of leftovers for lunch today.  My mother, who is gluten intollerent, enjoyed her beef chow fun.  Round it off with a large Tsing Tao & some tea & you will not be disappointed.  Though premiture, we enjoyed hearing KOIT's Christmas music & they also had Chinese TV going.  They have a lot of regulars as Nancy knows a lot of them.  Keep up the good work guys Nancy & staff.
author: Brian S.

description:
I find myself coming back everytime I crave for shanghai dumplings and noodles. The lady who owns the place is super friendly as well as the rest of the staff. We ordered 2 orders of the shanghai dumplings, one order of the shanghai noodles, green onion pancakes and potstickers-  total was $28.00. 

What a hidden gem!
author: M W.

description:
[M]ona: 4 Stars
[W]ayne: 4 Stars
Average: 4 Stars

+ Good chicken salad
+ Lunch menu is cheap
+ Affordable for the entire family
+ Children friendly and nice staff
+ Takeout Coupons

[W] This is a good spot on Noriega for all those people who aren't willing to go into Chinatown for the real stuff. The dishes that I really enjoy is the chicken salad and their Hong Kong style crispy noodles. I ordered take-out the other day and tried their Mandarin Chicken which was really good as well!

If you eat in, it's always the usual same two people. The nice lady and the server which looks like a big old bear that you can't understand. All I ever understand from him is when he says "you want rice?" other than that, it sounds like jibberish but its ok.

When ordering take-out, normally you would expect to get rice for free (It is an Chinese place isn't it?), but no, they actually charge for rice! As being Chinese myself I think that is ridiculous. I think that was the only down side. Other than that, I recommend just eating at the restaurant itself. 

Don't forget, if you order out and order $15 bucks or more, I believe they give you a free chicken salad with their coupons on the take-out menu. They're not going to tell you about that so remember to look at the take-out menu first. 

Another thing weird about this place is that they have two separate menus. One for the Chinese people with their "special" stuff and a separate one for tourist. I don't understand why they need to do that but I find it annoying when they automatically stereotype me and give me the Chinese menu which I find very confusing. You'll understand what I mean when you see it yourself. 

The other menu is definitely much easier to order from because they split all the entrees into categories such as poultry, seafood, pork, beef, vegetables, etc.
author: Mona C.

description:
It took TWO HOURS for them to deliver my order.  (I was told 45 minutes.)  

After an hour, I called to see if there was a problem.  They assured me it was "on the way, ten minutes."  Twenty minutes later, I get a call from the driver asking me for my address.  Wait...what?  I already gave the restaurant my address an hour and twenty minutes ago when I ordered.  

The driver tells me I'll be there in ten minutes."

I'm not sure where this "ten minutes" keeps coming from, because it's fictitious.

The food itself is cold, greasy, and less than mediocre.  The main flavor is grease and salt.  This is worse than mall food court "chinese" food.

I called the restaurant and told them this entire situation was unacceptable.  The guy on the phone (same person who took my order) laughed it off and said, "My bad!"

I won't order from here again and I could never recommend this to anyone.
author: Lauren C.

description:
One word: OILY OILY OILY.

Okay that was three words, but you get the point. This is most likely the worst Chinese food i have EVER come across living 18 years in Sam Francisco. For Non-Bay Area people, this restaurant might not be bad, in fact, it might even come off as being delicious and authentic! But in comparison to the other Asian restaurants in San Francisco, eating here wasn't an enjoyable experience, The SOLE reason we came here was because we were being treated-but never again.

The waitresses and waiters were quite nice, but the restaurant was poorly lit and the menus were pretty old and grimy.

This is what we had:

Shanghai Tofu Thizad Soup - The soup was probably my favorite part of the meal. The broth itself was quite tasty, but the presentation itself was horrible. Taste definitely outweighed appearance in this case. It was definitely not something you would order if you saw it; it looked like it was a bunch of leftover dishes thrown into a soup and served on the spot.

Potstickers - Reading positive reviews on Yelp, I was a bit excited to try it, but my hopes were crushed as I had my first bite. Burnt. The insides weren't that bad, but the rest were soggy, not crispy at all! Bad move.

Shanghai Dumplings (XLB) - in XLB, you're usually looking for a paper thin dumpling with luscious juicy meat inside. Here, the peel was CHEWY. Like gum. Not thin at all! And there was no "soup" in the dumpling either. Disappointed.

Prawns with Green Soy Beans - Initially, these were quite good, but as time went on, the oiliness got to me. There was this awful shininess to them. It looked like someone had literally took this dish tossed it in oil.

Shanghai Style Meatballs - These weren't that bad. The meat was quite tender, but mouth was wanting something more. It left me thinking about what it was missing rather than me enjoying it.

Bean Curd Sheet with Greens - Tofu didn't seem edible. It was rock hard! No comment.

Shredded Pork with Yellow Chives and Tofu - Took one bite and set it down. Too oily and fake. Enough said.

Come here only if there is a world apocalypse and you happen to be craving Chinese food. And this just happens to be the LAST STANDING Chinese restaurant in SF.
author: Calvin H.

description: Good food, and very great service. They were excellent about cleaning up after our large party and bringing everything we ask. We might be back with the family!
author: Lauren E.

description: I use this place for my Grubhub meals all the time.  They are fast and Delicious. I have never been to the restaurant but love that they are close to me and provide such great food.  I am Veg so they have great options and I even play around with Tofu and Vegetables in the Walnut Prawn sauce with Walnuts. bomb. Also Mongolian Tofu is really great.
author: Debey G.

description: Ordered from this place through Waiters on Wheels. When I got my Peking Noodles, I was sure it was the wrong order because there was a large soup thing that looked exactly like my hot and sour soup. Upon calling the restaurant, they told me that the soup thing goes with the noodles. Um, nowhere on the website does it indicate it's Peking Noodle SOUP. Not what I expected, not what I wanted, not what I liked.
author: Cindy T.

description:
Amazing hot and sour soup... !!!

This restaurant is a hidden gem that not alot of people really know about. 
Best Chinese restaurant in the inner sunset
author: Lauren N.

description: Really good place for dinner.  Consistantly delicious Northern Chinese food.  Our family's go to place.
author: Eric C.

description:
So gf and i were getting hungry and decided to order off of grubhub and found this place and decided to try it.

what we ordered: 
Chicken with Vegetable Deluxe
Hong Kong Style Crispy Noodle
free: chicken salad
 
the good:
-came in 20 minutes which was less than the 48 minutes we were informed of
-had a coupons
-can order online

THE BAD:
-first both dishes are extremely oily 
-second the food was very bland
-Chicken with Vegetable Deluxe was basically thick sauce with tasteless chicken, a few cabbage, a single baby corn, maybe a mushroom or two and celery.
-Hong Kong Style Crispy Noodle- was the biggest disappointment. small clump of fried noodles, extremely salty sauce (msg which they should go easy on), what little beef there was tasted rather stale and had very little in terms of decent ingredients.

Results: my gf getting sick right after and i, 3 hrs later. i'm afraid of touching the free chicken salad.

i'm guessing take out is where this place cheaps out, and maybe they r much better when u eat in person. 
i'm hoping other places in sf are not as bad otherwise i'm just gonna eat Chinese in oakland.
author: Ivan D.

description:
gross. super greasy, very tasteless Chinese food-- which arrived in plastic bag filled with a puddle of residual grease. They also didn't want to deliver to us because there isn't easy parking in our area-- though I'm not sure where there is in SF-- and made us walk down the block to pick it up from them. 

poor quality food. bad customer service. don't bother.
author: Amy S.

description:
Nothing fancy about this place - Just good food at an affordable price among a street full of restaurants. The cuisine is Shanghainese/Taiwanese which is different from the typical Cantonese restaurants a couple blocks away (Jumbo and Hing Lung), but I guess some people can' t even tell the difference. In fact, the crowd here seems to be more Taiwanese vs HK/Cantonese, meaning its a bit more quiet. No offense. The food here is not as oily as typical authentic Chinese food.

Definitely try their dumplings - the wrapper is not too thick yet it was able to hold all that meat and juice. Mmmm...Meat juice. JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description: The Hot & Sour soup saves this place from getting a single star rating. I can overlook no lunch menu on the weekend, totally acceptable. What's not acceptable is the Chinese Chicken Salad that tasted like if Burger King ever tried a whacky version of their menu and tried some Chinese dishes. While trying to eat this I felt like Aston Kutcher was about to jump out behind the non-existent wait staff and 'Punk' me. If only I had cash I could have eaten next door.
author: Chris D.

description:
It has been my favorite restaurant since 1995, when I move to the US and used to live a couple of blocks away from this place. 
I still love this place, even though I do not get to come here often from, since I live in San Jose.
Their walnut prawns, garlic string bean chicken, Peking beef, and won ton soup, are the best I have tried and I have been to at least 20 Chinese restaurants in my life. The prices are great, and the service is amazing. They sort of treat you like family, especially if you come there often :).
author: Lina K.

description:
The only time I go here is for their Beef Chow Fun.  It is one of the best although I must admit that today's Beef Chow Fun was a bit sub-substard and oily.  I will give their Beef Chow Fun one more try -- if it's the same as today's, then they must have changed their chef or something.  

The only time my husband goes there is for the free Hot and Sour soup.  They give you a free bowl with the meal.  I'm not a fan of this soup, so I usually just give it to my husband. He loves it!!  

Shanghai dumplings are good here too.  Not the best, but it's affordable.  They give you 6 for $5.
author: Jannie Q.

description:
You need to order from the Chinese menu, I love their spicy fish fillet with tofu, Shanghai style meat balls, beef and tendon appetizer, vegetarian duck and many more authentic dishes. 

If you order from the American menu, you will get greasy Chinese American food.
author: SJ L.

description: Better than the usual Chinese delivery in the neighborhood.
author: Patrick S.

description:
Came here to try out their Xiao Loong Baos and Onion Pancakes.

A friend of a friend actually owns this and recommended to try it if I liked spicy foods.

I was with the bf who is totally weaksauce on anything spicy, so we avoided ordering any items with more than 1 chilli pepper on the menu.

Dishes we got:
Xiao Loong bao
Crab Xiao Loong bao - never seen this before, so we HAD to try it.
Onion pancakes
Sizzling rice soup
Chef's Chicken with basil

My family is a huge xiao loong bao fan so we eat it pretty often. From my experiences, I think Peking had OK ones. I mean, the skin wasn't too thick or too thin, but the thinner the better. The soup inside these little treasures are THE most important. The soup in the ones here weren't as flavorful as I wanted them to be, but for some place in the sunset, I'd come back! Saves me a trip to c-town! In addition to the regular ones, the crab ones were pretty tasty too. The crab meat I expected were softer but it's alright. If I were to choose to order the regular or crab ones next time, it'll definitely be the regular ones.

Onion pancakes are one of my fav dishes....the ones here were a little disappointing. Just a tad too oily....but it was cripsy. I think the ones I prefer would be thinner and flakier. 

The sizzling soup was delish...good amounts of veggies and scallops. Maybe just a bit on the salty side, but not bad. A good soup to try out!

Last, the Chef's chicken with basil. It came wrapped in foil. You open it up, and the strong scent of basil and spices come out. Yum!! They use white meat chicken, so that's a super plus for me! It wasn't too spicy, but it was perfect for some weaksauce I was sitting across from. I think this was one of my fav dishes here tonight. 

I would recommend trying out this place if you like xiao loong baos and love shanghai food....I'm definitely coming back here to try some of their other dishes!!
author: Christina T.

description:
3 stars for convenient take out menu. The double sided page, is packed with menu items, and comes with coupons for free fried rice, or free soda. 
Favorites include the wonton soup, potstickers, mushu chicken, and my sister enjoys the crispy fried noodles with gravy. Food is always prepared well, not greasy, and arrives quickly.
author: Netty L.

description: I've been eating here for 25 years. Still the best hot and sour soup in sf. I also love sizzling rice soup.
author: Tina L.

description:
Tried something new for delivery and this was top rated in the restaurants that were near me.  I got Kung Pao Chicken, Pot Stickers, Chinese Chive Pancake, Boiled Meat Dumpling, and free pork chow fun.  

The pot stickers were delishous and the sauce that came with them were very yum.  I loved the chow fun! But i think i could eat those noodles every day every meal.  The Chinese chive pancakes are more like p'zone with stuffing.  Better to eat this one fresh from the kitchen where it's still hot and crispy.  

The rest of the meal was just so so.  The kung pao chicken i felt was bland.  There was little flavor, but it's such a common dish.  The boiled meat dumplings were the same bland flavor, but the dipping sauce for it made up for that.  

Also, I forgot to order rice with my meal, but luckily I'm asian so I have a rice pot that always has at least some rice in it at all times!~
author: Ryan Y.

description:
My parents wanted to try this place since a friend of theirs recommended it.  According to the menu and the owners, the food they serve is Sichuan and Shanghai.  The chef owner is Taiwanese.  

The place is quite large, but very outdated.  The service (the owner served us) was super friendly.  Since she recommended Sichuan items, we stuck with her recommendations except for the Shanghai dumplings.

Crab & Pork Shanghai Dumplings -   2 stars.  The skin was too thick but the filling was good with lot of soup and crab flavor. 

Hot & Sour soup - 2 stars.  Not spicy or sour enough.  

Sichuan Boiled Beef (not sure if the translation is correct here) - 2 stars.  I would give this dish 4 stars, but it was way too salty.  Flavor and texture were excellent, but it's almost not edible because of the soy/salt.    

Pea Sprouts with garlic - 4 stars.  This was outstanding.  Perfectly cooked, slightly crisp.

Spicy Beef Tendon - 4 stars.  This was the best item we had.  The tendon was sliced very thin with very nice Sichuan spices: garlic, chili, sichuan peppercorn, hot oil, cilantro, g. onions.  Like most Sichuan places, they tone their spices down for the largely Cantonese clientele.  So, if you like spicy, ask for extra spicy and extra sichuan peppercorn which will bring it closer to the authentic version.

Pan fried red bean pastry - 3 stars.  A touch greasy, but tasty.   

The Sichuan flavors are authentic, but unfortunately, the food is too  salty.
author: Paul K.

description:
My friend and i were looking for a new takeout.
Our friends recomended peking.
We called them without a menue to look at. Mistake no 1
We were told they had a couple of dinner options.
You could get a $10.95 or a $11.95 meal for example but not both?
We also asked for a menue, so next time we woud"nt have to guess at it.
The food  came on time without the menue.
We ordered two $10.95 dinners, with a sde of chow mein.
The wonton soup was ok, takeout soup comes from a different pot than dine in, otherwise these restaurants would"nt be able to stay in buisness with bildgewater they pass off as soup.
The chowmein was just noodles, probably from the takeout skillet.
The meat dish had sweet sauce on it ugh.
The fried rice, i make better my self and i HATE to cook!
I give this place a two toilet roll, cause my friend had to use two rolls after she started digesting this poor excuse for takeout food .
My friends say, it"s better if you go inside, but that defeats the purpose of takeout.
What i don"t understand is WHY, in this city, can"t you find a decent restaurant, good food, reasonable price.
Whe i go to salem oregon, free parking downtown, with cafe"s and all kinds of restaurants on most every block, with REAl bakery"s too
Breakfast for $6, dinner for$15 top notch too
My friends and i either go to marin or down on the penensula for dinner.
Wont you please help,


Signed

 Starving in the parkside
author: billyubba f.

description: Came here because I live nearby. It was empty on a Saturday night, so that must have not been a good sign. We wanted some take out. I ordered the tofu with vegetables and a soy base sauce. My husband had the black bean noodles. The portions were big but we paid $20 for just 2 plates and rice. The food was ok, nothing spectacular, but not good enough to make me want to come back again. Not to mention that the aren't too many vegetarian items (there's lots with tofu and meat).
author: Crys L.

description:
We've been ordering delivery from here for quiet a while now.  Within 30 mins, dinner is on the table. For $25, 2 green chives pancakes with vermicelli, eggs and dry Shrimp.. the fillings are seasoned to PErfection BUT.. the skin are too crispy like the Crab Wonton,   "Lion Head" Meatballs  are a bit tough but they are HUGE   literally the size of a peach...  The Cumin Lamb was Delicious.... lamb is soooooooo tender.. and if you don't like the smell of lamb.. opt for the Hot spicy version. .. it helps with the smell A LOT...
And the Chicken Chow Mein is FREE.
author: Pearl H.

description: We didn't read the Yelp reviews before ordering from Eat24 and now I'm sad we didn't.  Like the previous review, we ordered the Sizzling Chicken, Beef & Broccoli, pot stickers and hot & sour soup.  The beef was RANCID -- ew!!! The chicken had pieces of gristle in it and the pot stickers were soggy.  My boyfriend is eating the hot & sour soup, that he says he's enjoying, but I'm not brave enough.  Will NOT be ordering from here again.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Peking Restaurant is a fine alternative to Little Beijing for Mandarin/Szechwan (non-Cantonese) Chinese cuisine when you don't want to deal with the latter's ever-moody owner.  You will always be greeted with a smile and a warm welcome at Peking Restaurant.

The beef dishes here are better than the chicken dishes. I enjoy the Orange Beef, Beef with String Beans, Hunan Beef, and Spicy Beef with Flaming Chili Oil (a.k.a. Water Cooked Beef).  I am also a fan of the Spicy Beef Noodle Soup.  The Mao Pao Tofu is probably one of the best I've tasted in the City, but it can be inconsistent at times.  The Peking Fried Chicken Wings are a huge disappointment. They cut the wings in half!

Peking Restaurant has two menus. The first menu has all of the dishes one would expect of a Chinese restaurant. The other features more native cuisine. The good thing is that the more native menu is in English, but the wait staff always seems hesitant in giving it out unless you are of the same tribe.  Ask for it!  Some of the best dishes here are on that menu.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description:
In the same way that you expect lobsters from Maine, steak from Texas and clam chowder from Boston, China is packed with a plethora of different localized of cuisines.  If you want some authentic Shanghainese food, this is the place to go.

For the uninitiated, the culture in Shanghai is completely different from that of Taiwan or Hong Kong.  And while most people in Shanghai speak Mandarin, most are bilingual and speak Shanghainese, a local dialect that's so different that it's unintelligible to people that speak either Cantonese or Mandarin.

Now, I'm not an expert on Chinese cuisine, but I do know that if you order your Mongolian beef and kung pao chicken here you're completely missing out on the experience.  Reading reviews like, "This is the most authentic General Tso's Chicken that I've ever had!" make me cringe.

I came here with my mom and my sister for a quiet family dinner.  According to my mom (who's originally from Shanghai), Peking Restaurant recently hired a new Shanghainese chef.  She had no problem speaking to the host and the waitress in Shanghainese.  (Even though I can't understand a lick of it, it's not everyday I get to see my parents speaking to strangers in Shanghainese.  When I was backpacking through Europe, I remember my ears perking up every time I heard somebody speaking American English, it was an immediate and familiar touchstone.  I'm sure for my parents, even though they've been living here for the past forty years or so, it must be the same way for them when they hear somebody speaking Shanghainese.)

So what's good here?  I'm pretty squeamish when it comes to particular foods, even still, the fish head soup was really good.  Savory broth with chunks of white fish meat served family style.  Delicious.  And while I didn't see any fish head itself, I'm sure the $20 price is enough to scare most people away.

Of course, there are two of my favorites, the siu long bow and the Shanghainese noodles.  Siu long bow is a Shanghainese style dumpling that's filled with a pork filling and steaming broth.  When you eat it, you want to be careful not to pop it and let it spill all over your plate, otherwise you've missed out on what makes the dish so special.  And for a small restaurant on Noriega street, the siu long bow here was surprisingly good.  Shanghainese fried noodles are always good.  The egg noodles are thicker than your average noodle, and are fried with soy sauce and a little bit of pork.  Sure it's packed with lots of starch and lots of oil, but it's damn good.

After our meal, the chef came out to greet us with some free desert on the house--a nice touch for a neighborhood establishment.  If you're interested in trying out some good Shanghainese food, give Peking restaurant a shot.  Just ask for a few recommendations before you cave in and order the shrimp fried rice, OK?
author: Tony L.

description:
This is your obligatory "gwai lo" (white people) Chinese restaurant surrounded by otherwise mostly authentic Chinese cuisine. When I worked around the corner, I would sometimes drop by for a diversion from the other places, but it was definitely far from my favorite. Also, my manager often told me to pick up his order from here, so I figured I would probably get something as well.

This is the kind of place where Caucasians go to eat Chinese food if they are too intimidated to enter the other joints. Most of the times I have come here, I was the only Chinese guy in the entire restaurant besides the employees. They even greeted me in English as I entered the door.

Flavoring is decent, but very Americanized. It's certainly a step above the watered down mall style Chinese food at Panda Express or Mr. Chau's, but it is in the same vein. If you look around, and notice that the most popular dishes are broccoli beef, kung pao chicken, and Mongolian beef, this should tell you the whole story. Oh, BTW, you are probably thinking that my manager is Caucasian, right? Wrong. He's a 100% Twinkie Chinese guy who can't speak a lick of Chinese. That explains it all.
author: Eric W.

description:
We tried several dishes here: the beef chow fun, chicken corn soup, chicken mu shu, and the string beans with pork. The dishes were all nice and tasty, everything tasted fresh.

Prices were cheap. About $8 per dish but there was plenty to share and take home. Portions were also generous.

Service was not bad, as this place got more crowded though we had to call over our waiters for the check.

A nice, sized restaurant. Good for family dining. Seemed to be a bit old fashioned but clean.
author: Miss H K.

description:
Dad was craving dumplings/pot stickers, and San Tung on Irving was PACKED.  After all, it was a little after 6:30 on a Sunday night.  So we decided to see what we'd find on Noriega.  Randomly picked this place - we checked out the menu beforehand, and a few things did catch our eye.  It was a little dingy on the inside, but still clean.

We ended up ordering:

Boiled Shrimp w/ Chinese Chives Dumplings:  Tasty little dumplings.  The vinegar that came with these was a little sweet.  We probably should have added soy sauce from our table.

Pot Stickers:  Crispy!  I loved how the skin was not too thick.  The meat inside was okay.

Snow Cabbage & Pork w/ Rice Cakes:  Not a very large plate, but very tasty.  The snow cabbage was fresh, not the preserved kind.  Plus, there were juicy black mushrooms too.  Didn't appear particularly oily.  Probably my favorite dish of the meal.

Shanghai-Style Clay Pot: Basically, a clay pot of rice cooked with fatty pork and veggies.  A little bit on the salty side, and we had to pick out the fatty pork.

The names of these dishes are a little different because some of these items are not on the take-out menu!  I usually like to grab one as a reference, but it didn't do me much good this time.  

Yes, most of the other patrons in the restaurant did not appear to be Chinese.  And the tea was just a tea bag in water.  But we picked out a few of the Northern Chinese dishes and were actually quite pleased with the end result.  The dishes we ordered were a little on the small side, while the teriyaki platter and sweet and sour pork on the other table looked ginormous.  

3 to 3.5 stars - I actually might come back to this place when I'm craving the Northern Chinese-style cooking.  Mostly Mandarin-speaking, but they do have someone who understands Cantonese if you don't feel like flexing your English skills.  

One of the waiters/possibly an owner appeared to be a hit with the female patrons.  Saw him teaching them how to use chopsticks and even feeding one of them with her chopsticks.  Now that's service!
author: Tinna H.

description:
The name of this restaurant caught my eyes.  Peking is the capital of China, but since 1949, Beijing is the new word instead. Yes, the city to host the 2008 Olympics.

On the other hand, Peking Duck is still called Peking Duck.  It became well-known to the world during Henry Kissinger first visit to China. The Secretary of State told everyone that he is in love with this new dish. In the 70s, China and Peking Duck were very hot topics.

I believe this restaurant was opened after Nixon's first visit to China in order to take advantage of the 'Peking' popularity.  Unfortunately, the restaurant is as old as its name, from its setting to the food quality.

My friend ordered the almond chicken lunch special which is served with hot and sour soup and steamed rice, $5.50.  I ordered the chicken with garlic, $5.50.  Both dishes tasted very similar, overly sweet. The only difference is the almond and the garlic. $5.50 is cheap for all the food and tea, but the overall experience is bad.

I will definitely try another place next time!
author: Peter Y.

description:
I love, love love love love the Peking Restaurant. Their sizzling rice soup is my favorite food, ever, and my go-to hangover cure, even if it means a trip allll the way out to 20th and Noriega. 

The staff is very nice and has remembered and been kind to my fam since we were runts and my dad would take us here for special occasions. OK, to put it mildly, the G. clan is not a clan you can bring everywhere. We are 8 loud and rowdy peeps deep and were loud and obnox long before any Tsingtao was involved. But the waiters there always liked us, even that time when my brother decided to stand up on the table and randomly yell every swear word he had learned by age 4, which were um disconcertingly numerous. 

Even though I have ordered the same exact thing here since the mid-80s, it's always delish and served with a side of happy nostalgia. Peking, I heartcha.
author: Annie G.

description:
time for a remodel. this place has been here for a long time and it shows. i had two dishes tonight that could have been nicknamed - heaven and hell. the Mongolian beef was flavorful, lean meat, and just the right amount of spice. the Peking style chicken wings were inedible. the wings were cut in half, dipped in heavy batter, and had an indistinguishable sweet sauce. on my recent trip to Beijing, i never saw any chicken dish remotely like that travesty. 
proceed with caution. Your mileage may vary.
author: Jeff W.

description: Honestly, I have not found a better Chinese dining restaurant in the city! This place is the bomb. I love their fish filet with chinese wince sauce. As well as their Pork dumplings and Shanghai Sticky Rice Siu Mai! By the way you have to ask for the chinese menu if you are white. I highly recommend you ask specifically for the Chinese menu if you want  the best (there is english on it also)
author: Mike P.

description:
I'll start by saying this place looked dingier than the others on this small block, but we decided to come here.  The primary reason was that I had brought a credit card and most of the places around took cash only or a different type of cc.

The staff here was extremely nice.  We had three different people waiting on us, which made everything very efficient and pleasing to my serving days of time past.

The first dish we ordered was the Seaweed Egg Flower soup.  When they brought it out, it looked amazing.  The taste, however, was a little lacking.  It really didn't set a good first impression as I noticed the peas had seemingly come from a frozen bag and the mushrooms were just slightly gritty, but overall it wasn't bad.  

The next dish, the Hong Kong style crispy noodles were really good.  I actually enjoyed these a lot.  It had plenty of meat and vegetables on top of the very crispy noodles.  This certainly set a better tone with me.  Peking beef came out next.  I've never really noticed any adverse effects to eating MSG, but I'm sure it was in the food.  Still, how can you give up a great dish just because of the umami components?  The beef was perfectly light crisp-fried and had garlic, green onions, and ginger--all of which I'm a major fan!  This really hit the spot with me.  It certainly ended my dining experience well.

All-in-all this isn't a bad little joint.  It certainly wasn't the busiest on the block, which leads me to believe I may want to come back and check out those places as well, but this place was fine in its own right.
author: Brent A.

description:
I cannot believe I just awarded Peking 3 stars.  I used to love this place.  However, it all changed today.  How sad.

Let's step back for a moment.  I started coming here ten years ago, and the place never disappointed.  On the outside, it's your typical Chinese restaurant with your usual decor and your usual fish tanks.  

However, if you dig a little deeper, you'd find out something else.  It's the kind of place where the owners, a.k.a. the waiter and the waitress, are always nice, helpful, friendly and even funny.  It's the kind of place where I used to tip even when I got takeout because I wanted to be nice.  It's the kind of place where the hot and sour soup is so good, my dad swears it has the ability to cure a cold.

All the food here is good, but not spectacular.  Peking restaurant had only one signature dish worth trying - Peking beef.  It was my favorite thing to order here; one might even call it my guilty pleasure.  Today my two friends and I went to Peking for a late lunch/early dinner.  We ordered some appetizers while I was waiting for my Peking beef.

When my dish came, I noticed that something wasn't quite right.  My dish looked . . . different.  I am not sure whether they changed the chef or otherwise messed with near perfection, but it wasn't the Peking beef of yore.   It was a greasier, fatter, blander, doughier version of the dish I had grown to love.  I was so shocked and disappointed, even the crispy rice noodles didn't cheer me up.

I never thought I'd say this, but I don't think I have a reason to come back to Peking.  The fortune cookie, however, was dead on.  It promised me a "pleasant journey to a faraway destination" right after I booked a trip to the East Coast.  How did they know???
author: Yan G.

description:
If you want overly-saucy cheap,Chinese food, then come here. My boss suggested this place for lunch, so we had no choice.  For 6 of us we ordered from their lunch menu ($4.75 per dish), which came with rice and soup.  The sweet and spicy soup had a good kick to it.  We started with two orders of the pot stickers, which were pan fried for that crispy outer layer.  For the lunch dishes we ordered:  

Sweet and Sour Pork,
Kung Pao Chicken,
Spicy Sze-chuan Prawns,
Spicy Egg Plant In Sze-chuan Sauce, and 
some tofu dish

This was plenty to of food!  Make sure you drink LOTS of water and/or tea because everything was drenched in some type of sauce. It definitely felt heavy afterwards...food coma for sure. 

Negative: the place itself seemed very old since the tables were sticky.  So don't come here for the environment.
author: Lisa C.

description:
Your standard Chinese restaurant. Nothing catering to vegetarians on the menu so I went with my standard vegetable fried rice. I was a bit concerned about my order because the waitress was confused when I told her vegetable fried rice. For some reason she looked at my menu, then looked at me, and finally asked it I wanted fried rice or chow mein. It took a bit of explaining that I did not eat meat and only wanted vegetables in my fried rice. Other than that everything was all good. The waitress was nice and checked on us occasionally. I tend to be picky about fried rice but this was a good one. It was flavorful and they did not overdo it on the vegetable. I hate when I order vegetable fried rice and they serve me vegetables mixed with a little rice. 

Would go back for a quick take out.
author: Richard C.

description:
Peking is consistently good.  We get fast delivery all the time.  Some of our staples are MuShu Pork, cashew chicken, shanghi dumplings, sweet n sour chicken.   We recently tried the chive pancake and it was delicious!

This place is a way better version of americanized chinese food.  It feels like it was made for the American Born Chinese person.  You know like Tomato Beef and such. 

The only complaint I have is sometimes the green bell peppers that come in the dishes (like sweet n sour chicken/pork) taste like they are old and have been soaking in liquid for days.   Please fix this issue Peking.
author: culinary q.

description:
I love their selection on their lunch menu which includes a cup of hot & sour soup. I don't normally eat hot and sour soup but this place changed my mind.

The pot stickers are pretty much some the best I've eaten. The garlic chicken was pretty good. The vegetables were also very fresh and crisp which complemented the meal nicely.

On another trip to Peking my friend ordered the  sweet & sour pork (I know it's a tourist food)  so I decided to try it. I was very pleasantly surprised at how well made this dish was. They cook the pork and then add the sauce on top after the meat is done, unlike most places that let the sauce soak through the meat and make the entire dish soggy.

Overall I would not hesitate to go back there for lunch or dinner just as long as you start off with the hot & sour soup followed by their pot stickers.
author: Mario O.

description:
AVOID...
Was craving chinese food, went on grubhub, and picked this one... horrible... had some chicken dish that was okay, and it went down from there... the potstickers are some of the worst i've had... took a couple bites of the mandarian beef and it was so bad i had to throw the rest out... the hot and sour soup was bland at best but still edible
definitely not eating from here again
author: Joe K.

description:
Finally a Chinese place in San Francisco that is not disgusting.

The food was quite good, delivery on time, and prices decent. Also came with a free soup, which was tasty.

Will be ordering from them again.
author: Artem R.

description:
We drove by this place a million times thinking it was a American-Chinese restaurant...but we were desperate one day and went there for lunch.  Wow, this place rocks!  The food is actually AUTHENTIC!  My girlfriend is from China and we don't have many authentic (non-cantonese) places in The City.  So it was a joy to find this place.  The decor hasn't changed since 1983 it seems, which makes it only 4 stars.

Another authentic chinese restaurant!
author: Sir Paul L.

description: Peking was my first taste of Chinese food. My family would go here every other Sunday with friends for years when I was little. Although I haven't been here in years, I still remember this place very well. The pot stickers were fabulous, as were the chicken and beef dumplings. And my all time favorite was their hot and sour soup. Peking is your typical Americanized Chinese restaurant common all over SF. Is Peking the best Chinese restaurant in the city? Not at all! But it was tasty and it was the Chinese restaurant of my childhood. Shame on me for waiting 3 years to do a review on it!
author: David D.

description: This place is also one of favorite chinese restaurants in Noriega. I have eaten here a few times. Peking Restaurant for me sort of reminds me of Gazebo and Little Beijing very small restaurants.
author: William B.

description:
I actually really like it here.  Been coming here since a child when they had Tien Fu next door.  Now that was a great 1-2 punch of restaurants.  But maybe their cuisines were too similar for them to survive next to each other and Tien Fu had another location so they moved on and concentrated on their other restaurant.  

In any case, this is a no-frills restaurant.  It always seems dark and morbid in there.  Service is simple and professional and the food is pretty good.  It's never as packed as San Tung on Irving and is a decent alternative to that restaurant if you are craving some garlic chicken wings and other dishes that have a bit of spice.  

Hopefully, it's still around when I have kids so I can tell them that I've been coming here since I was about your age....  hehehe...
author: Mark W.

description:
i'm chinese, but because i'm chinese i never know what to order at chinese restaurants. this is because no matter what age i am, my parents will always order chinese food for me (unless of course i'm not eating with them). this isn't because i don't know what i'm eating, i just never know what to get.

but that's hardly relevant. my parents were dying to try this place out because my dad had eaten here almost two decades ago and they always pass it by. peking restaurant is strange to me because it has the name of a beijing style restaurant (peking being another way to say beijing) but they specialize in shanghai and szechuan cuisine. for those who don't know, szechuan cuisine tends to be very spicy while shanghai cuisine is lighter in flavor. 

anyway, i don't remember all the things we've ordered here (we've made two trips so far) and the ones i do remember i can't recall their names because we order in chinese, but the ones that stand out are the szechuan dish with the spicy fish and tofu, their flat rice cakes (i really don't know what these are called in english, in mandarin it's "cao nian gao") and some other spicy shit i can't remember. how i ever got elite status is a mystery to me.

now what i would recommend to anyone trying this place out (and i have not done this yet) is to try their steamed soup dumplings (or shanghai style dumplings or some variant of that name) because that is the staple food of shanghai cuisine, so if they do that right then it's all good. they're the meat dumplings with the insane amount of juiciness in them.

people complaining about how old and bad this place looks need to stop. now i love the food of my people but WHO GIVES A CRAP. america has already made the chinese restaurant look horrible. that's what we're all used to, anyway, so i don't see how this could be an issue with anyone. 

either way, the place is very reasonably priced, it doesn't feel very dirty (you reviewers saying otherwise need to search deep within your souls and check yourselves, then go to actual dirty chinese joints cuz u know we got them on lock), and the food can be very good, you just have to know what to order. which i clearly don't. thanks for tuning in, yelp.
author: Edmund C.

description:
We came here to eat a light dumpling lunch...because of one of the newspaper reviews stating that this place cooks to order (meaning that the dumplings are hand made to order and not sitting in the freezer the night before.

I really love the shanghai dumplings, the pot stickers were also quite good as well as the vegetable mini dumplings selection. The one thing we added to the set was beef, choy and sliced finger dough pieces dish which was a bit too savory for my company. It needed to lessen the soy a bit.

There weren't many people in the restaurant and yet it was a bit difficult to get our check...this doesn't make sense if the staff were busy but they weren't.  The bathroom is really small with the low flow toilets (please don't get me off on this other pet peeve of mine, I do know that these toilets help reduce water waste, but it has to be flushed twice for it to be useful negating the savings)

Otherwise, it was an okay experience.
author: Pauline L.

description:
If i go to a chinese restaurant I haven't been to before I usually try the mongolian beef. It seems like every place makes it different, but it's one of my favorite dishes to order. At Peking theirs has more of a garlic flavor to it than extra spice, but still good nonetheless. The seafood chow mein was also good. The wait staff is unbelievably friendly and i appreciated that rareity.

Food: 3.5
Ambiance: 2.5
Service: 4.5
Whole Experience: 3.5
author: Jen Y.

description:
I had a craving for some good ol' chinese food...and was so overwhelmed by all the results that came up on Yelp, that i just said screw it. i'm just gonna drive down to Noreiga (closest) and hopefully pop into something.  I decided after looking down at my gas gauge that Peking Restaurant would have to do. 

  I ordered the hot & sour soup (delicious! hearty, has lots of tofu, that black seaweed thingy, has a definite kick and prawns!), the beef chow fun (not too bad, a little bit on the bland side, needs some more seasoning or sauce) and the hunan style beef (the sauce tastes great...the beef itself didn't taste like beef at all, just very chewy fatness, and not the gooey good kind either).  

 All in all, the hot & sour soup was worth it.
author: Lulu C.

description: My friends and i decided to actually eat at the restaurant we enjoy so much and...it was an awesome experience. All i can say the that energetic guy who works there is entraining and a blast to be around.
author: Vespa Fox C.

description:
horrible lemon chicken i wouldn't wish on my worst enemy!    :(
i gave it one star cuz i got 2 fortunes in one cookie! hehe.
author: KatieRae A.

description: It's bad. i didn't even finish the meal. It was too scary and didn't want to get sick.
author: Ralph C.

description:
I had such a fun time having dinner here last night!  The guy who owns it (I think he owns it)  with his wife (I think it's his wife), are the funniest people ever!  

His wife is so sweet, for example, she will say "thank you" to herself for doing something, then say "your welcome" to herself too, it was so cute I had such a hard time not giggling!  

Then the old man, was hilarious!  He kept playing jokes on the tables and just made the whole dining experience lite and fun!  

The food was good too!  My friend and I shared one of the family specials and it was so much food.  The won ton soup was really good!

I have ordered to go from here before and it is good, but the whole experience of going to the restaurant was fun, lite and cute!  They even had pink table cloths and pink napkins...cute!
author: Sara P.

description: We have a problem here. We love what we order so much that we have not tried most of what they offer. Tomato Beef Chow Mein, Fried Prawns, Combo Fried Rice, Combination Vegetables, Sweet and Sour Pork. We have ordered these items to our home many times and they are ALWAYS OUTSTANDING. The food is even better in their quaint restaurant. The décor isn't new by any means, but it has been cleaned, ie.-no dust and filth. The service in house is wonderful, timely but not immediate. I hate when you go into a restaurant and your food comes out in one minute. It means that it's already made in the back. Here it comes to you in stages. They bring you one dish, then the next one, then the next, etc.,. Just right. Anyhow back to the food. The Tomato Beef Chow Mein is awesomely tomatoey and NOT GREASY with lots and lots of tender beef, noodles not mushy, flavored just right. Thank you Peking. The Fried Prawns are hot and crispy, battered just right and the prawns are succulent underneath...mmm...dipped in the hot mustard and sweet and sour sauce. The Combo Vegetables are cooked in a chicken broth thickened with corn starch and done to perfection...little ears of corn, whole small mushrooms...veges never tasted so good. Combo Fried rice comes with plenty of chicken, beef, shrimp and is not greasy The sweet and sour pork is decent, and they don't skimp on the pineapple and it's not greasy . We love the simplicity of the menu. This place is so unassuming too. The prices are fair. Maybe we will expand our ordering choices one day, but for now we are hooked on these items. Kudos Peking PLEASE KEEP IT UP AND DONT CHANGE  THANK YOU.
author: Hope C.

description:
I love Peking!  The service is excellent and the service people are always gracious and helpful.  I love their sweet and sour pork and garlic chicken.  We frequently order delivery; the service is prompt and courteous.  The restaurant needs some updating in appearance but it certainly does not affect the great food!

Yelp:  You need to know that Peking Restaurant is NOT in the Outer Sunset but Central Sunset, near 21st Avenue.  Sunset Boulevard (between 36th and 37th Avenue) divides Central Sunset from Outer Sunset.
author: Diana S.

description: I ordered over twenty dollars of food and was pretty insulted when they charged me 50 cents for extra white vinegar to dip my potstickers in. I thought the food way ways to greasy and honestly, I wasnt very impressed. In spite of all that, I decided to give them a second chance, and boy was that a mistake. This place is horrible! I
author: Jacqueline G.

description: I love their combination fried rice and hot&sour soup. They do need to remodel but it's not gonna stop me from coming there as long as the food is good, fresh and cheap.
author: Lena T.

description:
We read a few positive reviews and were excited. Priced well and menu LOOKS good. Food was sub par chinese and we realized shortly after we started eating that we both felt the affects of MSG. We asked the waiter if they used MSG and after checking with the kitchen came back and told us they had and that next time we should specify to NOT use MSG. We were not aware that the culinary world still actually used MSG in food...now I must go pop an advil to get rid of MSG induced headache.
Cannot recommend that you eat here unless MSG is your thang.
author: Tee G.

description: My second favorite chinese restaurant in the city. Of the two, this one delivers to my house :)  Great food, right price and they will make off the menu orders for you if you ask for them. Gave them four stars and not five because there is another place that i prefer....but not very close to home. See my reviews for the other place.
author: Sergei A.

description:
We went here after a joke of an experience at a San Bruno "chinese restaurant". (I reviewed that experience separately).  It was our first time here , and we were very pleasantly surprised. 

 The service was very good, a nice diversity of food, excellent beef with noodles, sizzling rice soup," Reasonably priced, friendly, and just good food." There was also an excellent, diverse array of dishes to choose from, and the waiter made an excellent recommendation for us.

 We love 'authentic' chinese cuisine, and very much enjoyed this restaurant. Well worth the drive into the city, and we'll definitely be back.
author: G L.

description: Decent enough place for a quick, cheap lunch. Lunch combinations come with rice & hot 'n sour soup for $4.75-$6. The twice-cooked pork had big, soft pieces of pork in it along with cabbage, red & bell peppers, bamboo shoots, onion, and some other vegetable I'm not sure what it was. The shrimp dumplings were tasty and choc-full-of something green.
author: Todd F.

description: For ten years now, I have made my way to the Peking Restaurant when in the Sunset and a Chinese food craving hits me.  The crispy duck is spiced right and the won ton soup is decent.  I like the fish tank and that they serve you tea, even if you are ordering take-out at the restaurant.
author: KarenG P.

description:
Ive been eaing at Peking restaurant for almost 20 years.  Just like any other restaurant, you need to know what to order here to get the good stuff.  Since most chinese restaurants around here are cantonese style, people are accustomed to ordering the cantonese dishes they usually order elsewhere.  This is your first mistake.  The dishes you need to order here are the more northern chinese stlyle dishes, not broccoli beef, sweet n sour pork, or lemon chicken.  Go to panda express for that.  All the traditional vegetable dishes, slow cooked soups are delicious.  Must order the Wu Xi spareribs, and the hot n sour soup here is the BEST you'll have anywhere.  Its rich and hearty with fresh ingredients.  There are plenty of fresh fresh prawns in it and I can seriously order the soup sometimes as a stand alone meal.  I think most people are turned off by this place because its not cantonese food. And in response to Eric W. who said ....

A)Flavoring is decent, but very Americanized. It's certainly a step above the watered down mall style Chinese food 

B)Oh, BTW, you are probably thinking that my manager is Caucasian, right? Wrong. He's a 100% Twinkie Chinese guy who can't speak a lick of Chinese. That explains it all

Most people are used to eating MSG laden food, its not watered down, theres just no MSG to fool you. And I know the owners and entire staff, and contrary to your beliefs, no he doesnt speak Cantonese (chinese), they speak mandarin (chinese).
author: david w.

description: We eat at Peking very often, but last Saturday, because we didn't feel like getting dressed and going out, we decided to order our food for delivery.  It took 1 1/2 hours to deliver and they are only 10 minutes from our house!!  After 45 minutes, we called the restaurant and were told that the food is already in transit.  However, it took another 45 minutes before it even arrived.  That was really ridiculous.  We love the food and the restaurant, but there is something very wrong when it takes this long to deliver it.  Next time, we'll just get it to go.
author: olga d.

description:
Service = 5 (fast, courteous, flexible ordering)
Decor = 3 
Quality of food = 4
author: Stephen F.

description: I like it here. I've been here a couple times and always enjoy the food. On the upper end of 3 star good food. Last time I had the prawns on a sizzling hot plate and lemon chicken. I usually don't like lemon chicken, but it was just right. Our server was very entertaining. Funny older guy who made a joke every time he came by. I was happy eating here and will go back when I want some dependably good Chinese food.
author: Jessica W.

description: Food is just ok.  every dish is hit or miss.  the pot stickers tasted bland and the seafood didn't seem fresh (do not order clams).  The best dish was the hot n sour soup.  I would only come here just for the soup, but nothing else.
author: Alfred L.

description: I have been coming here for the weekend brunch menu--green onion pancake, fried bread (yum!), veggie shanghai noodles, veggie potstickers.  Best on this block compared with two other restaurants that offer this type of food.  The staff is friendly and attentive.
author: Kim T.

description: Terrible food. I placed a large order for the party of 12 people. I did not check the order at the restaurant because I had 2 large boxes of food. Well, bad mistake!. When I got to the party location and started opening up boxes, more then half of the order had incorrect items, not what we ordered. Food tasted terribly, too spicy, overcooked. I will never go back to this restaurant. Thanks for screwing up my party!
author: yelena b.

description: It's a small restaurant, and uh.. sorta clean. The dishes aren't huge, but they're not that bad either. The waitress was nice, but seemed somewhat paranoid. Food was so-so. Not bad.
author: Katherine C.

description: bomb beef and broccoli, chicken fried rice, & pot stickers since i was a little girl.
author: Jade D.

description: for delivery we ordered: mixed fried rice (chicken, shrimp, beef), mu shu pork, and onion fried pancake. because we spent over $15 it came with a free chicken salad which was actually the only good dish out of everything we ordered. the onion pancake and mu shu were average and nothing to woot about. shockingly the fried rice was the worst out of everything. it came with big shrimps. more rice than anything else and rather bland and it looked more like steamed rice. fried rice is the simplest thing you can make so if a chinese restaurant cant even do that right it's not worth eating at so we wont be ordering here again.
author: Helen L.

description: Best Chinese food in the city! Always treated like family here, great waitstaff. The food is amazing here, you cannot go wrong. Their hot and sour soup is one of many great things on the menu.
author: Daniel K.

description:
Food itself is good.  But one waitress-owner is just (an octave) way too loud and high pitched; I guess that is what one reviewer earlier described as "paranoid."  Sometimes there is a young girl in her 20's (owner's daughter) with long hair who I counted touched her hair 14 times in two minutes during order-taking for just two customers. 

There is a local health law governing restuarants saying each time an employee touches the hair he/she is supoosed to wash the hands.
author: Eric L.

description: I've been coming here for 3 years.  We always get a table, even with a party of eight with no reservation!  The food here is one of the best in the sunset district.  I've tried several.  I recommend the Sesame Chicken which isn't on the menu.  My second choice is the Walnut Prawns.  Ask for extra sauce. Nancy is very kind and so are the rest of the staff.  Maybe they are nicer to me because I frequent here several times a month.  When friends from out of town come to visit, Peking is always their request.  It's a great place with children.  Last night I spent $80.00 which included dinner for eight, tip, drinks, 9 dishes and food left over to go.  This is my choice.  Parking is a pain, but if you double park in front while the rest of your party goes in to get seated, almost always someone walks out and a space is available.  That's the trick!
author: Ramon W.

description: It's relatively clean. The portions are smaller, but it helps curb the gorging factor.  Had their mu-shu vegetable dish, the pancakes could use a little work, but the veggie part was pretty delicious. We had some mao pa tofu; made with a simple sauce but still had good portions of ground pork, pretty good too. I'd go back if I was in the area.
author: Jaejean K.

description:
recently stopped in the midst of a chinese-food binge.  we had:

shanghai spare ribs
fish in a spicy soup

spare ribs were pretty gross, but the fish soup was pretty solid.  i probably won't go out of my way to return, but might order the fish soup for delivery sometime.
author: Dustin E.

description: The reason I got a YELP account was to give this restaurant a bad review.
author: Emily S.

description: Northern Chinese food. Pretty typical. Taste is also pretty northern. Home cooking. As a Chinese, I like this place because it reminded me hometown. But all what I can remember about this place is salt, salt and salt....
author: Vat S.

description: Very tasty and affordable place. They make great hot and sour soup. Keep going back there. 5 stars for food, 4 stars for ambience.
author: Igor O.

description: This restaurant has the best Hot and Sour Soup in the city or at least the best that I have had so far.  It is a very clean restaurant and everyone on the staff has a smile.  Terrific lunch menu at a very reasonable price.
author: Aaron M.

description: I've been coming here since 1987. My gung fu Sifu, who was from HK brought me here. He said that he had eaten at many Chinese places around the US, Canada, and throughout Asia and he said that the chef here is outstanding. I fell in love with this place right away and can't find a better Chinese restaurant anywhere in the bay area. It's not fancy or trendy, but the food is amazing. Sure I've had off meals, but for the most part it's consistently great. My wife and all of her family also come here. My sister in law went to Paris and was taken to this trendy new, highly rated Eurasian fusion restaurant. After spending over $100.00 per person she said that Peking was way better. Try the Pot stickers, the chicken salad, onion pancakes, the combo chow mein or combo fried rice. The best hot and sour , won ton, and sizzling rice soups on the planet, (his broth makes all the difference in the world). The garlic chicken, and kung pao chicken the Mongolian beef, mango beef and the Sze-chuan prawns are all unique and all incredibly good. I can go on and on about their wonderful dishes. I've honestly looked for over 20 years to find a better and closer Chinese restaurant to my house in San Ramon, but you simply can't beat Peking. John the owner is a master trained chef, and his wife and staff are so warm and friendly and always remember me, my wife and kids by name. I really, really love this place.
author: Johny A.
